title: Can't I use internet without a router? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s hard to make sure of your meaning with this question. Here’s an answer that is technically correct: It is possible, but probably not with modern equipment. To get on the internet, you need a contract with a service provider, a modem, and a computer. You will need to connect your computer to the modem. A router is usually included with the modem, because it allows more than one device to share the internet connection. But it is not required if you don’t need to share the connection. If you want to connect with a phone, you will need WiFi. The router/modem usually has a WiFi access point. WiFi requires a router, because there is a built-in assumption that the WiFi signal will be available to more than one device. So, you can connect without a router provided you have a service contract, a modem, an Ethernet cable, and a computer. This is how dial-up connections used to work. The modem either was inside the computer, or connected with a serial cable. *However*, modern computers all use Ethernet, and assume a router will be available to set important Ethernet parameters. I’m not sure how one would get around this. Connecting without a router using modern equipment would be difficult at best, and maybe not possible. I don’t know of any Ethernet modem that doesn’t include a router. If that doesn’t answer your question, here’s an alternate answer. In the US, you can get on the internet for free at most public libraries, many stores, and some restaurants. Just connect your device to their public or guests WiFi. Sometimes their WiFi will require a password. Sometimes you will have to go to their site and accept their terms and conditions. Retail outlets sometimes limit the amount of time you can be connected. In this case, the library or store provides everything you need except the computer or phone (including a router). If you don’t have a computer, libraries will usually also make the computer available for free. None of these options will be fast enough for gaming, but it doesn’t get any more free than that.

Q: How do I get a WiFi/broadband connection at home without routers? You can get an Internet connection over DSL/Cable/Fibre cabled connections or satellite or cellular wireless delivery. In some locations there are ISPs that offer very localised WiFi, but these are not common. With cabled and satellite connections you need a modem to convert the ISP signal into a digital signal for connection to a device or a router. Generally, without a router you can connect only one device to the modem. You could have a wireless access point, but it would support only a single device. Remember, WiFi is an alternative to an Ethernet connection, and with the exception of the localised ISP provided WiFi I mentioned above, WiFi does not come from the ISP but is produced by your router or access point. I suspect you should reconsider your “without routers” requirement.

You simply cannot get WiFi (a wireless network connection technology) without a router. Without a router, your wireless devices would have nothing to communicate with. However, the modem which your Internet Service Provider gives you may contain a built-in router. If you want a wired Internet connection for only one device, and you don’t care at all about security, you can live without a router[1]. A router is responsible for linking multiple devices together and for protecting you. It has a firewall which can protect your home Internet from cyberattacks. You can plug your computer directly into your modem using an Ethernet cable and get a working Internet connection, but you would be directly exposing it to the Internet. Anyone with some skills could hack into it and use it to host content for an illegal website. Footnotes[1] Do I Need a Router if I Only Have One Computer?

Kind of depends what you mean by a router. On a local level, the router is what connects you to the rest of the world. But on a global level a router is what connects one part of the internet to another part of it. For example the part of the internet that is in America to the part of the internet that is in Britain. Or Russia. Or South Africa. Or France. And if you imagine trying to send a letter from your house (in South West Germany) to your pen pal’s house (in North East Australia) just by throwing it up in the air and kind of hoping it gets there by finding its own way…… well that’s basically how the internet would function without routers. Just sit and picture that for a minute or so. And then another minute. And a minute after that. Because that would be pretty much all you could do for the rest of time if there were no routers throughout the entire world. So - to sum up - no. The internet can’t work without routers because the computers would not know where to send the data. And we would be (not to put too fine a point on it) monumentally fucked. Have a nice day :)

What we call a router today is actually several devices shoveled into one. It’s a router, modem, WAP, and switch. The functions are share net, get net, wireless net, and wired net. You can buy them all separately if you wish. Getting on the net without a router means you need a pure modem and an ethernet cable to a pc. But you can connect just one device. It is impossible to get wifi without a router because the router function is what allows multiple devices to share one net connection. Technically you can attach a WAP to a PC and make the PC route but then you’re still using a router. Practically speaking the answer is NO. Why in the world would you even want to?

Yes you can use internet without a router but not without a modem. A modem is a device that translates between ethernet and phone signals. All internet systems I can think of use a modem somewhere. You can get 4g modems fiber modems and most older computers have a modem built in if you are desperate. A router just splits this signal into several via ethernet or WiFi. There may be systems where you never see the modem like ethernet to the apartment when there is a large modem and router in the basement or office of a large building and everyone pays for internet via the building manager.

Like the other responders, I’m not entirely sure what you’re actually asking. However, with reservations, it can be done. Your tablet or phone will come with the ability to connect to WiFi. All modern laptops are the same. So, find somewhere with an unsecured WiFi network, preferably one that permits access. Connect and the Internet is yours. Here in Australia, that’s usually a library, city centre or shopping centre. Also some trains. If you’re asking how to do it from home, then Dennis (below) has laid it all out. As an alternative approach, a mobile plan will usually have a data quota associated with it, and there’s no effort at all needed. As long as you’re in range of a cell that will accept your provider, you’re connected.
